9.heading: Reagan, Ronald.
9.title: "Did It Ever Occur to You that a Massive Explosion Inside Mr. Reagan's Brain might Adversely Affect his Subsequent Mental Performance?"
9.author: G
notes: Summary: Roland Hedley is testifying at a hearing about hurling an incendiary device at the President's fornix.

10.heading: Reagan, Ronald.
10.title: Edible Secrets : a Food Tour of Classified US History
10.author: Michael Hoerger & Mia Partlow ; illustrations by Nate Powell.
notes: Summary (from publisher via SkyRiver): What do top-secret CIA assassination plots, Black Panther arrests, and Reaganomics have in common? Food, of course! Michael Hoerger and Mia Partlow collect, contextualize and graphically narrate declassified government documents with food as a theme! Over 500,000 declassified memos, debriefings and transcripts were combed to uncover some of the most important and iconic people and narratives from US history. Providing a voyeuristic insight into the US government, these documents are like reality TV for politicos and foodies: Assassinations by milkshake, subliminal popcorn cravings, Reagan's love of hydroponics, and what could be Fred Hampton's most radical action: giving ice cream to small children.

11.heading: Reagan, Ronald.

notes: Summary: Hedley begins the tour of the brain of Ronald Reagan, talking about 5-cent Cokes, Burma Shave signs, Angola, Iran, Korea, Cyprus, Cuba, Lebanon, and using terminology like fornix, hypothalamus, and marbles.

60.heading: Reaganomics.
60.title: You Don't Have to Fuck People Over to Survive
60.author: by Seth Tobocman.
notes: Summary (from SkyRiver): Collects many of Tobocman's most enduring images in a powerhouse assemblage that cuts right to the heart of 1980s activism. All the high (and low) points are there: the imprisonment of Mumia Abu-Jamal; the rise of Reaganomics; the struggle against apartheid; the Miami Race Riots; and, of course, the turf wars that dominated the city of New York, as activists and low-income families alike demanded their rights to the city's abandoned buildings.

contents.title: Prisoners of the war on drugs

contents.author: Susan Willmarth, Ellen Miller-Mack and Lois Ahrens.
contents.title: women and their children

notes: Summary (from SkyRiver): One out of every hundred adults in the U.S. is in prison. This book provides a crash course in what drives mass incarceration, the human and community costs, and how to stop the numbers from going even higher. This volume collects three comic books published by the Real Cost of Prisons Project. The stories and statistical information in each comic book are thoroughly researched and documented.

226.heading: Real Girls.
226.title: "I Need Your Love" 8 p. in New Romances, no. 12
226.author: [No author]
notes: Summary (by Amy Lazet): At 17 years of age, Leslie feels her life has not been going well. She has always been a tomboy, and never a real girl. As she sees her older sister Marianne dating, she realizes she has been denying her inner femininity. Then Dan comes home. Dan is a childhood friend back from college for a break, and he tries to persuade Leslie to act and dress like a girl. He even tries to kiss her, but she rebuffs him. Later when Leslie sees Dan out with Marianne she realizes she has loved Dan all along. Leslie overhears Marianne telling their father that she and Dan are a serious couple, and decides to make Dan jealous by getting a makeover. She returns home looking elegant to find Dan waiting for her. He and Marianne had never cared for each other, but they had agreed to go out in the hope of persuading Leslie to look and act like a girl. Blissfully happy, Leslie kisses Dan and renounces her immature, boyish ways.
